elements.content: A series of metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) functionalized with urea hydrogen-bonding groups has been synthesized and structurally analyzed by single-crystal X-ray diffraction to evaluate the efficacy of anion coordination by urea within the structural constraints of the MOFs. We found that urea-based functionalities may be used for anion binding within metal−organic frameworks when the tendency for urea···urea self-association is decreased by strengthening the intramolecular CH···O hydrogen bonding of N-phenyl substituents to the carbonyl oxygen atom. Theoretical calculations indicate that N,N‘-bis(m-pyridyl)urea (BPU) and N,N‘-bis(m-cyanophenyl)urea (BCPU) should have enhanced hydrogen-bonding donor abilities toward anions and decreased tendencies to self-associate into hydrogen-bonded tapes compared to other disubstituted ureas. Accordingly, BPU and BCPU were incorporated in MOFs as linkers through coordination of various Zn, Cu, and Ag transition metal salts, including Zn(ClO4)2, ZnSO4, Cu(NO3)2, Cu(CF3SO3)2, AgNO3, and AgSO3CH3. Structural analysis by single-crystal X-ray diffraction showed that these linkers are versatile anion binders, capable of chelate hydrogen bonding to all of the oxoanions explored. Anion coordination by the urea functionalities was found to successfully compete with urea self-association in all cases except for that of charge-diffuse perchlorate.

Theoretical calculations indicate that N,N‘-bis(m-pyridyl)urea (BPU) and N,N‘-bis(m-cyanophenyl)urea (BCPU) should have enhanced hydrogen-bonding donor abilities toward anions and decreased tendencies to self-associate into hydrogen-bonded tapes compared to other disubstituted ureas. Accordingly, BPU and BCPU were incorporated in MOFs as linkers through coordination of various Zn, Cu, and Ag transition metal salts, including Zn(ClO4)2, ZnSO4, Cu(NO3)2, Cu(CF3SO3)2, AgNO3, and AgSO3CH3. Structural analysis by single-crystal X-ray diffraction showed that these linkers are versatile anion binders, capable of chelate hydrogen bonding to all of the oxoanions explored. Anion coordination by the urea functionalities was found to successfully compete with urea self-association in all cases except for that of charge-diffuse perchlorate.

elements.content: Chelate binding of various oxoanions in coordination polymers built from organic linkers functionalized with urea groups has been demonstrated by X-ray structural analysis. The linkers were designed so that the CO group from urea forms relatively strong intramolecular C−H···O hydrogen bonds, thus inhibiting the typical intermolecular urea···urea hydrogen bonds that would otherwise neutralize the anion-binding sites.
elements.clean_text: Chelate binding of various oxoanions in coordination polymers built from organic linkers functionalized with urea groups has been demonstrated by X-ray structural analysis. The linkers were designed so that the CO group from urea forms relatively strong intramolecular C-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds, thus inhibiting the typical intermolecular urea⋅⋅⋅urea hydrogen bonds that would otherwise neutralize the anion-binding sites.

elements.content: Metal−organic frameworks (MOFs), or coordination polymers, have recently emerged as a promising new class of materials that combine the characteristics of inorganic networks, such as stability and crystallinity, with versatility and structural diversity of organic structures. These materials are easily accessible by self-assembly of transition metal cations with various organic linkers and are often amenable to detailed structural characterization by X-ray crystallography, which facilitates their rational design. When neutral linkers are employed, the resulting frameworks are cationic and intrinsically include anions for charge balance. Accordingly, some MOFs have been reported to function as anion exchangers. The anion exchange process can be solvent-mediated, involving dissolution of the initial framework and recrystallization of the final one, as recently demonstrated in a one-dimensional coordination polymer.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), or coordination polymers, have recently emerged as a promising new class of materials that combine the characteristics of inorganic networks, such as stability and crystallinity, with versatility and structural diversity of organic structures. These materials are easily accessible by self-assembly of transition metal cations with various organic linkers and are often amenable to detailed structural characterization by X-ray crystallography, which facilitates their rational design. When neutral linkers are employed, the resulting frameworks are cationic and intrinsically include anions for charge balance. Accordingly, some MOFs have been reported to function as anion exchangers. The anion exchange process can be solvent-mediated, involving dissolution of the initial framework and recrystallization of the final one, as recently demonstrated in a one-dimensional coordination polymer.

elements.content: In our quest for new receptors for applications to anion complexation and separation, we have become interested in MOFs as potential anion-binding hosts. Our approach toward this end is to functionalize these materials with hydrogen-bonding groups that would act as specific coordination sites for the included anion. We are particularly attracted by urea groups, as they are known to form chelate hydrogen bonding to oxoanions, which can provide enhanced binding strength and recognition abilities. However, ureas are also known to persistently self-associate into hydrogen-bonded tapes, which if formed inside MOFs would render them unusable for anion binding and recognition (Figure ).

elements.content: Two previous structural studies on urea-functionalized MOFs containing linkers L1 and L2 (Chart ) showed either urea self-association or the absence of the chelate hydrogen bonding to the anion (nitrate), which was apparently disrupted by hydrogen bonding to the included water solvent. More recently, Steed et al. demonstrated chelate hydrogen bonding of nitrate in a coordination polymer made from linker L3 with one pyridine group directly attached to urea. Our recent work involving L4 as an MOF linker resulted in unprecedented sulfate binding by six urea groups in a total of 12 hydrogen bonds, which represents the highest coordination number observed for sulfate in a natural or synthetic host. However, our attempts to bind other oxoanions with lower charge density than sulfate, such as AcO-, NO3 -, CH3SO3 -, or BF4 -, using L4, resulted only in ligand self-association by urea···urea hydrogen bonds. The need to design urea-containing linkers with stronger hydrogen-bonding donor abilities and lower tendency for self-association became thus apparent. Herein we report the design, synthesis, and structural characterization of MOFs containing the N,N‘-bis(m-pyridyl)urea (BPU)10 and N,N‘-bis(m-cyanophenyl)urea (BCPU) linkers, which show great versatility in binding various anions including SO4 2-, NO3 -, CH3SO3 -, CF3SO3 -, and ClO4 -.

As expected, aryl-substituted ureas are significantly stronger hydrogen-bonding donors compared to analogous alkyl-substituted derivatives, most likely as a result of the electron withdrawing character of the aryl rings through a combination of inductive and conjugation effects. We therefore reasoned that the incorporation of N,N‘-diarylurea groups into our linkers should greatly enhance the anion-binding properties of the resulting MOFs. Such groups have been successfully utilized for the design of discrete coordination complexes that showed binding of anions with relatively low charge density like NO3 - or PF6 -, and recently a dipyridylurea−MOF that binds ClO4 - was reported. The self-association of ureas remains competitive though, especially when the less basic anions are targeted, or when anion binding by multiple urea groups is intended, as complexation by each urea incrementally decreases the charge density on the anion.

The self-association of ureas remains competitive though, especially when the less basic anions are targeted, or when anion binding by multiple urea groups is intended, as complexation by each urea incrementally decreases the charge density on the anion.

elements.content: In our search for a way to inhibit urea···urea hydrogen bonding, we found inspiration in the seminal study of Etter et al., who showed that N,N‘-bis(m-nitrophenyl)urea has a decreased tendency to self-associate in the solid state, which corresponded with its increased ability to cocrystallize with various weak hydrogen-bonding acceptor guest molecules. Etter rationalized these findings based on the enhanced acidity of the H atom ortho to the nitro group, which translated into stronger intramolecular C−H···O hydrogen bonding to the urea's carbonyl and accordingly a decreased ability of this group to engage in intermolecular hydrogen bonding. This hypothesis was supported by the observation that while most other diarylureas displayed dihedral angles between their aromatic rings and urea groups ranging between 26° and 46° to facilitate the formation of urea···urea hydrogen bonding, the bis(m-nitrophenyl)urea had a nearly planar conformation, consistent with the presence of C−H···O intramolecular hydrogen bonds. Etter's structural evidence is consistent with our high-level quantum mechanical calculations (MP2/aug-cc-pVDZ) showing that the nitro group increases the rotation barrier around the N-aryl bond from 2.4 kcal/mol in phenylurea to 3.2 kcal/mol in m-nitrophenylurea. Additionally, we found that the nitro group significantly enhances the hydrogen-bonding donating ability of urea resulting in a 13.2 kcal/mol increase in nitrate-binding energy relative to diphenylurea (Table ).
elements.clean_text: In our search for a way to inhibit urea⋅⋅⋅urea hydrogen bonding, we found inspiration in the seminal study of Etter et al., who showed that N,N‘-bis(m-nitrophenyl)urea has a decreased tendency to self-associate in the solid state, which corresponded with its increased ability to cocrystallize with various weak hydrogen-bonding acceptor guest molecules. Etter rationalized these findings based on the enhanced acidity of the H atom ortho to the nitro group, which translated into stronger intramolecular C-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonding to the urea's carbonyl and accordingly a decreased ability of this group to engage in intermolecular hydrogen bonding. This hypothesis was supported by the observation that while most other diarylureas displayed dihedral angles between their aromatic rings and urea groups ranging between 26° and 46° to facilitate the formation of urea⋅⋅⋅urea hydrogen bonding, the bis(m-nitrophenyl)urea had a nearly planar conformation, consistent with the presence of C-H⋅⋅⋅O intramolecular hydrogen bonds. Etter's structural evidence is consistent with our high-level quantum mechanical calculations (MP2/aug-cc-pVDZ) showing that the nitro group increases the rotation barrier around the N-aryl bond from 2.4 kcal/mol in phenylurea to 3.2 kcal/mol in m-nitrophenylurea. Additionally, we found that the nitro group significantly enhances the hydrogen-bonding donating ability of urea resulting in a 13.2 kcal/mol increase in nitrate-binding energy relative to diphenylurea (Table ).

elements.content: By analogy with bis(m-nitrophenyl)urea, we reasoned that replacing the Ph group with pyridine or m-CN−Ph, which also have good electron withdrawing characteristics, would have comparable effects on the hydrogen-bonding abilities of their corresponding urea groups. Our calculations indeed found N-aryl rotation barriers for pyridylurea (2.9 kcal/mol) and m-cyanophenylurea (3.2 kcal/mol) that are similar with the analogous value calculated for m-nitrophenylurea. We also found a significant increase in nitrate binding by BPU and BCPU of 6.4 and 12.3 kcal/mol, respectively, relative to diphenylurea (Table ). Finally, it was expected that metal complexation by pyridine or -CN upon incorporation of BPU or BCPU into MOFs would further improve the electron-withdrawing character of these groups, thereby enhancing the anion-binding abilities of ureas in these linkers.

Finally, it was expected that metal complexation by pyridine or -CN upon incorporation of BPU or BCPU into MOFs would further improve the electron-withdrawing character of these groups, thereby enhancing the anion-binding abilities of ureas in these linkers.

elements.content: Structural Analysis of BPU and BCPU. A conformational analysis of the BPU (B3LYP/6-31G*) found three low-energy conformers that differ with respect to the dihedral angle between the pyridine rings and the urea group. While all three conformers display perfectly flat geometries, each pyridine ring may assume two possible orientations relative to the urea group, with the N atom either syn or anti relative to the CO group (Figure a). The anti−anti isomer was found computationally to be the most stable conformation, with the syn−anti and syn−syn being 1.6 and 3.2 kcal/mol higher in energy, respectively.

elements.content: BPU crystallized from acetone/toluene in the less stable syn−syn conformation, as found by single crystal X-ray crystallography (Figure b). The C2-symmetrical BPU molecule is nearly flat, with the pyridine rings forming a dihedral angle of 4.1° relative to urea. This allows intramolecular C−H···O hydrogen-bond formation, with an H···O distance of 2.160 Å. Accordingly, as in the analogous bis(m-nitrophenyl)urea, no urea···urea hydrogen bonds were observed in this structure.
elements.clean_text: BPU crystallized from acetone/toluene in the less stable syn-syn conformation, as found by single crystal X-ray crystallography (Figure b). The C2-symmetrical BPU molecule is nearly flat, with the pyridine rings forming a dihedral angle of 4.1° relative to urea. This allows intramolecular C-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen-bond formation, with an H⋅⋅⋅O distance of 2.160 Å. Accordingly, as in the analogous bis(m-nitrophenyl)urea, no urea⋅⋅⋅urea hydrogen bonds were observed in this structure.

elements.content: BPU crystallized as a dihydrate from EtOH/H2O, and the X-ray structural analysis revealed the presence of the most stable anti−anti conformer in this case (Figure c). The BPU assumes again a nearly planar geometry with pyridine−urea dihedral angles of 1.8 and 4.7°, which favors the formation of intramolecular C−H···O hydrogen bonds with observed H···O distances of 2.29 and 2.26 Å, respectively. As in the other structure, no urea···urea hydrogen bonds were formed; instead, the urea interacts with the weaker hydrogen-bond acceptor, water. Thus, as designed, both isolated crystalline forms of BPU showed the absence of urea self-association, which was correlated with the presence of intramolecular C−H···O interactions.

elements.content: Like BPU, BCPU has three planar conformations with the anti−anti one being the most stable and the syn−anti and syn−syn being 0.4 and 1.0 kcal/mol higher in energy, respectively (B3LYP/6-31G*). BCPU crystallized from acetone/EtOH in the less stable syn−syn conformation, with the two CNPh rings, however, being significantly twisted relative to urea by 27.3 and 30.8°, which allowed the urea groups to self-associate by hydrogen bonding (Figure ). However, only one of the two NH donors participates to these interactions, with the remaining NH donor hydrogen bonding to a CN group from a neighboring chain. Thus, although the urea···urea hydrogen bonds were present in this case, they were significantly perturbed by the CN groups.

elements.content: Crystallization of BCPU from acetone/water resulted in the formation of a monohydrate, with the BCPU assuming the most stable anti−anti conformation. With a dihedral angle of 5.6°, one of the CNPh rings is nearly coplanar with urea and forms an intramolecular C−H···O interaction with an observed H···O distance of 2.29 Å. The second CNPh group is, however, significantly twisted relative to the urea group by 21.0°, which resulted in longer C−H···O interactions of 2.35 Å. Nevertheless, no urea···urea hydrogen bonds were present in this case, with the urea group hydrogen bonding a water molecule instead (Figure ).

elements.content: BPU as an Anion-Binding MOF Linker:  (a) SO 4 2 - Coordination. Slow diffusion of an ethanol solution of BPU into an aqueous solution of ZnSO4 yielded a one-dimensional (1D) coordination polymer with the composition [Zn(SO4)(BPU)(H2O)3](EtOH) (1). Each zinc is coordinated by two pyridine groups, three water molecules, and a unidentate sulfate, arranged in an octahedral geometry. The BPU linker adopts the syn−anti conformation and is connected by the Zn nodes into a zigzag chain (Figure ). One of the pyridine rings is nearly coplanar with urea (dihedral angle of 3.8°), which results in an intramolecular C−H···O hydrogen bond with an H···O contact distance of 2.27 Å. The second pyridine is twisted relative to urea by 19.5°. The urea group coordinates the sulfate through chelate hydrogen bonding (H···O = 2.01 Å, 2.09 Å; <N−H···O = 165.8°, 166.8°). The sulfate is additionally hydrogen bonded to five water molecules and also coordinated to a zinc node (Figure b), thus cross-linking four adjacent coordination chains.

The second pyridine is twisted relative to urea by 19.5°. The urea group coordinates the sulfate through chelate hydrogen bonding (H⋅⋅⋅O = 2.01 Å, 2.09 Å; <N-H⋅⋅⋅O = 165.8°, 166.8°). elements.content: When an acetone solution of the BPU was diffused into an aqueous solution of ZnSO4, a different 1D coordination polymer was obtained, with the composition [Zn(SO4)(BPU)(H2O)2.5](H2O)3.5 (2). There are two types of zinc cations present:  one coordinated octahedrally by two pyridines, two water molecules, and two unidentate sulfate anions, and the second one coordinated in a trigonal bipyramid geometry by two pyridines and three water molecules. The BPU assumes the syn−syn conformation and links the zinc nodes into an extended coordination chain (Figure ). Both pyridine rings are quasicoplanar with the urea group (pyridine−urea dihedrals of 2.8 and 2.9°) and form intramolecular C−H···O hydrogen bonds with H···O distances of 2.09 Å. Accordingly, the urea coordinates the sulfate in a chelate mode, with observed N−H···O contact distances that are shorter than in the previous structure (H···O = 1.92 Å, 2.08 Å; <N−H···O = 171.5°, 166.4°). Additionally, the sulfate coordinates a zinc atom and hydrogen bonds to six water molecules (Figure b), thus interlinking the chains in an intricate three-dimensional (3D) network.

elements.content: (b) NO 3 - Coordination. Slow diffusion of a solution of Cu(NO3)2 in wet methanol into a solution of BPU in CH2Cl2 yielded a two-dimensional (2D) coordination polymer with the composition [Cu(NO3)(BPU)2](NO3)(H2O)2.5(MeOH)0.5 (3), as determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction and elemental analysis. The copper nodes are octahedrally coordinated by four pyridines in the basal plane and two monodentate nitrate ions in the apical positions. There are two unique BPU molecules in the unit cell, each in the syn−anti conformation. One pyridine ring in each of the two BPU linkers forms an intramolecular C−H···O hydrogen bond (H···O = 2.20 and 2.26 Å, respectively), facilitated by small pyridine−urea dihedral angles of 4.7° and 15.4°, respectively. The other corresponding pyridine rings, however, are significantly twisted relative to their urea groups by 53.8° and 39.3°, respectively. The BPU ligands link the copper nodes into an extended 2D coordination layer (Figure ), with the layers connected in the third dimension via coordination by a bridging nitrate anion. The second nitrate is hydrogen bonded in a chelate mode by two urea groups belonging to adjacent layers. The observed hydrogen-bonding parameters are H···O = 2.05 Å, 2.06 Å, 2.07 Å, 2.13 Å, and <N−H···O = 160.4°, 153.7°, 171.6°, 155.1°, respectively. Once again, no urea···urea hydrogen bonding was observed. The crystal contains 1D channels occupied by disordered solvent.
elements.clean_text: (b) NO  3   -    Coordination. Slow diffusion of a solution of Cu(NO3)2 in wet methanol into a solution of BPU in CH2Cl2 yielded a two-dimensional (2D) coordination polymer with the composition [Cu(NO3)(BPU)2](NO3)(H2O)2.5(MeOH)0.5 (3), as determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction and elemental analysis. The copper nodes are octahedrally coordinated by four pyridines in the basal plane and two monodentate nitrate ions in the apical positions. There are two unique BPU molecules in the unit cell, each in the syn-anti conformation. One pyridine ring in each of the two BPU linkers forms an intramolecular C-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bond (H⋅⋅⋅O = 2.20 and 2.26 Å, respectively), facilitated by small pyridine-urea dihedral angles of 4.7° and 15.4°, respectively. The other corresponding pyridine rings, however, are significantly twisted relative to their urea groups by 53.8° and 39.3°, respectively. The BPU ligands link the copper nodes into an extended 2D coordination layer (Figure ), with the layers connected in the third dimension via coordination by a bridging nitrate anion. The second nitrate is hydrogen bonded in a chelate mode by two urea groups belonging to adjacent layers. The observed hydrogen-bonding parameters are H⋅⋅⋅O = 2.05 Å, 2.06 Å, 2.07 Å, 2.13 Å, and <N-H⋅⋅⋅O = 160.4°, 153.7°, 171.6°, 155.1°, respectively. Once again, no urea⋅⋅⋅urea hydrogen bonding was observed. The crystal contains 1D channels occupied by disordered solvent.

elements.content: (c) CF 3 SO 3 - Coordination. A coordination polymer with the composition [Cu(BPU)2(H2O)](SO3CF3)(H2O) (4) was obtained by slow diffusion of BPU in ethanol into an aqueous solution of Cu(SO3CF3)2. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed a looped chain topology with copper nodes coordinated by four pyridine groups from different BPU linkers (Figure ). Additionally, a water molecule in the apical position completes the coordination environment of each copper center, which thus assumes a square-pyramidal geometry. The two unique BPU linkers in the crystal are both present in the syn−syn conformation, with one of their pyridine rings quasicoplanar with the ureas (dihedral angles of 9.1° and 3.6°) and the other corresponding pyridine rings twisted from the urea planes by 22.9° and 19.4°, respectively. This results in the formation of a short intramolecular C−H···O interaction (H···O = 2.24 and 2.15 Å) and a longer one (H···O = 2.27 and 2.22 Å) by each of the two unique ureas, respectively. Accordingly, each urea group forms chelate hydrogen bonding to a triflate anion, with observed NH···O contact distances of 2.06 Å, 2.13 Å, and 2.07 Å, 2.07 Å, and NHO angles of 154.1°, 154.7°, and 161.8°, and 170.4°, respectively. The triflates are further hydrogen bonded by a water molecule, which acts as a bridge connecting neighboring coordination chains in the crystal (Figure b).

elements.content: (d) ClO 4 - Coordination. Although our linkers were designed to have enhanced hydrogen-bonding donor abilities, the prospect of perchlorate binding inside MOFs appeared rather poor, as this anion is known to be an extremely weak base with very poor coordinating abilities. Our first attempt to bind ClO4 - by BPU was unsuccessful. Thus, self-assembly of BPU with Zn(ClO4)2 in CHCl3/EtOH resulted in the formation of a coordination polymer with the composition [Zn(BPU)2](ClO4)2 (5), which displayed a square-grid topology containing tetrahedral Zn nodes connected by BPU linkers in the anti− anti conformation (Figure ). The two pyridine rings in BPU are significantly twisted out of the urea plane by 34.5° and 41.1°, and the urea groups self-associate by hydrogen bonding thereby connecting the square grids into a 3D network, with neighboring grids offset by 0.5a. The ClO4 - anions are included in the resulting channels and form weak C−H···O interactions with the framework.

elements.content: Crystallization of BPU and Zn(ClO4)2 from EtOH/H2O resulted in the formation of a different crystalline phase with the composition [Zn(BPU)2(H2O)4](ClO4)2(BPU)2 (6). Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis indicated the formation of a C2-symmetrical discrete coordination complex comprising a zinc center hexacoordinated by two BPU ligands and four water molecules (Figure ). This complex is self-assembled via pyridine···H2O hydrogen bonding into an extended looped chain (Figure b). Two additional noncoordinating BPU molecules are included in the crystal. The coordinating BPU adopts an anti−anti conformation, with the pyridine rings twisted out of the urea plane by 15.9° and 22.2°. This allows the urea group to associate with a noncoordinating BPU molecule, via one NH···O hydrogen bond. The noncoordinating BPU is in the syn−anti conformation and, in contrast with the coordinating BPU, is nearly planar, with pyridine−urea dihedral angles of 4.0° and 11.9°. This disrupts the propagation of the urea···urea hydrogen-bonded chains, instead allowing the urea group in the coordinating BPU to chelate the ClO4 - with observed NH···O contact distances of 2.10 and 2.31 Å, and N−H−O angles of 163.4 and 162.5°, respectively.

elements.content: BCPU as an Anion-Binding MOF Linker:  (a) NO 3 - Coordination. Self-assembly of BCPU with AgNO3 in CHCl3/acetone/MeOH resulted in the formation of a helical coordination polymer with formula [Ag(NO3)(BCPU)] (7). Single crystal X-ray diffraction (Figure ) showed that the silver nodes are coordinated by two BCPU linkers and a nitrate anion. The BCPU assumes the syn−syn conformation and displays a relatively planar geometry, with pyridine−urea dihedral angles of 5.8° and 13.0°. As a result, the carbonyl group of the urea forms two intramolecular CH···O hydrogen bonds, with observed H···O contact distances of 2.24 and 2.28 Å, respectively. The urea binds the nitrate in a chelate mode, with N−H···O contact distances of 2.04 and 2.10 Å and N−H−O angles of 171.5° and 169.3°, respectively (Figure b). These urea−nitrate hydrogen bonds link the helices into extended 2D layers, as illustrated in Figure c.

elements.content: (b) CH 3 SO 3 - Coordination. Crystallization of BCPU in the presence of AgSO3CH3 from CHCl3/acetone/MeOH yielded a coordination polymer with the composition [Ag(SO3CH3)(BPU)2] (8). Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed the formation of a highly folded chain containing silver nodes and one BCPU linker. The silver centers are also coordinated by an additional BCPU acting as a terminal ligand, as well as a monodentate methanesulfonate anion (Figure ). The BCPU linker is in the syn−syn conformation, with its pyridine rings quasicoplanar with the urea (dihedrals of 6.7° and 9.1°), which results in relatively short CH···O contacts of 2.27 and 2.32 Å. The urea group hydrogen bonds a vertex of the methanesulfonate anion, with observed NH···O distances of 2.05 and 2.07 Å and N−H−O angles of 158.3° and 155.9°, correspondingly. The terminal BCPU ligand is also in the syn−syn conformation, with pyridine−urea dihedrals of 2.8° and 19.5° and CH···O contact distances of 2.15 and 2.19 Å. Its urea group binds the methanesulfonate in a chelate mode (NH···O = 1.99 Å, 2.12 Å; <N−H−O = 176.3°, 162.5°), thereby connecting the chains into layers.

elements.content: Through computation and experiment, it has been shown that the otherwise dominant tendency of substituted urea molecules to self-associate in the solid state may be greatly diminished or altogether defeated by strengthening the CH···O hydrogen-bonding interaction of the ortho hydrogen of an activated N-phenyl substituent with the urea carbonyl oxygen atom. This understanding opens the door to better use of urea moieties as functional units in MOFs for such purposes as anion coordination via chelate hydrogen bonding. An exploration of this concept was undertaken with BPU and BCPU linkers containing a urea group symmetrically substituted with pyridine or CNPh metal-coordinating ligands selected based on their enhanced hydrogen-bond donor abilities and their reduced tendencies to self-associate, similar to the bis(m-nitrophenyl)urea analogue. Structural analysis by single-crystal X-ray diffraction confirmed that these linkers are indeed versatile anion binders when incorporated into MOFs, forming chelate hydrogen bonds to various oxoanions with a wide range of basicities, such as SO4 2-, NO3 -, CH3SO3 -, CF3SO3 -, and ClO4 -. With one exception, when the weakly basic ClO4 - was involved, no self-association of the urea groups into hydrogen-bonded chains was observed, unlike other urea-containing MOF linkers previously studied. These results correlated with the presence of intramolecular C−H···O hydrogen bonding, strengthened by the enhanced acidity of the corresponding CH donors, which diminished the ability of the CO group to engage in intermolecular urea···urea hydrogen bonding.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Through computation and experiment, it has been shown that the otherwise dominant tendency of substituted urea molecules to self-associate in the solid state may be greatly diminished or altogether defeated by strengthening the CH⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen-bonding interaction of the ortho hydrogen of an activated N-phenyl substituent with the urea carbonyl oxygen atom. This understanding opens the door to better use of urea moieties as functional units in MOFs for such purposes as anion coordination via chelate hydrogen bonding. An exploration of this concept was undertaken with BPU and BCPU linkers containing a urea group symmetrically substituted with pyridine or CNPh metal-coordinating ligands selected based on their enhanced hydrogen-bond donor abilities and their reduced tendencies to self-associate, similar to the bis(m-nitrophenyl)urea analogue. Structural analysis by single-crystal X-ray diffraction confirmed that these linkers are indeed versatile anion binders when incorporated into MOFs, forming chelate hydrogen bonds to various oxoanions with a wide range of basicities, such as SO4 2-, NO3 -, CH3SO3 -, CF3SO3 -, and ClO4 -. With one exception, when the weakly basic ClO4 - was involved, no self-association of the urea groups into hydrogen-bonded chains was observed, unlike other urea-containing MOF linkers previously studied. These results correlated with the presence of intramolecular C-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonding, strengthened by the enhanced acidity of the corresponding CH donors, which diminished the ability of the CO group to engage in intermolecular urea⋅⋅⋅urea hydrogen bonding.

The structures of the MOFs examined provide a number of useful insights toward more effective anion binding within MOFs. First, diminished urea···urea hydrogen bonding requires a strong competing interaction with anions, and this depends on there being an electron-withdrawing aromatic substituent that both enhances NH hydrogen bonding to the anion and CH···O intramolecular hydrogen bonding to the urea oxygen atom. We have identified here two basic MOF linkers that can act as versatile anion-binding units and have a decreased tendency to self-associate by hydrogen bonding, but many other possibilities can be foreseen. Control of the syn−anti conformation of the aromatic substituent and a more planar configuration are desirable. As shown by the various structures studied, the slightly more stable anti−anti conformation was observed only in 4 of the 12 structures analyzed, suggesting that other factors such as crystal packing forces are more important. Anion coordination to metal nodes was a common feature in the structures, an apparent competing effect that must also be considered. Finally, a greater degree of complementarity in anion binding is sought. Chelate binding to oxoanion edges and vertices were both observed, in accord with molecular modeling. However, cooperativity between two urea groups in binding a single anion was only observed twice in eight structures. We are currently working on the design of more elaborate linkers incorporating multiple urea units positioned complementarily around the anion to achieve optimal shape recognition and selectivity.

N,N ‘ -Bis( m -pyridyl)urea (BPU). To a solution of nicotinic acid (1.23 g, 10 mmol) and triethylamine (1.4 mL) in 5 mL of dry DMF was added diphenyl phosphoryl azide (2.75 g, 10 mmol) in 1 mL of DMF and the mixture was stirred at room temperature under Ar for 1.5 h. The solution was then poured into 30 mL of water, extracted with 3 × 15 mL ether, and the ether layer was dried over anhydrous Na2SO4. Evaporation of the ether under vacuum yielded the nicotinyl azide intermediate as a white solid (0.83 g, 5.6 mmol), which was dissolved in 20 mL of toluene and dried over anhydrous Na2SO4. 3-Aminopyridine (0.53 g, 5.6 mmol) was added, and the resulting solution was refluxed for 1 h. The BPU product precipitated as a white crystalline solid that was collected by vacuum filtration, washed with toluene, and dried. elements.content: Theoretical Calculations. N-Aryl rotational barriers for phenylurea, m-nitrophenylurea, pyridylurea, and m-cyanophenylurea were calculated with the NWChem program16 at the MP2/aug-cc-pVDZ level of theory. The core electrons were frozen in all MP2 optimizations. The approximate location of stationary points on the potential energy surfaces for rotation about the N−C(aryl) bonds was found, and full geometry optimization of the minimum energy and transition state structures with tight geometry optimization cutoff was performed at the MP2/aug-cc-pVDZ level of theory. Frequencies were computed analytically at this level of theory to characterize each stationary point as a minimum or a transition state. Nitrate binding by various N,N‘-disubstituted ureas and conformational distribution of BPU and BCPU were calculated with density functional theory (DFT) at the B3LYP/6-31G* level of theory, using Spartan 04 (Wavefunction, Inc.)

elements.content: X-ray Crystallography. Single-crystal X-ray data were collected on a Bruker SMART APEX CCD diffractometer with fine-focus Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å), operated at 50 kV and 30 mA. All structures were solved by direct methods, except for 3, which was solved by the Patterson method. The structures were refined on F 2 using the SHELXTL software package. Absorption corrections were applied using SADABS, part of SHELXTL package. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms were placed in idealized positions and refined with a riding model, except for the water hydrogens, which were located from difference Fourier maps and refined isotropically. The severe disorder of the solvent molecules included in the crystal of 3 prevented proper refinement of their atomic parameters. The corresponding residual density was therefore treated with SQUEEZE, part of the PLATON software package, which found 81 e-/unit cell corresponding to 2.5 water molecules per formula unit. Pertinent crystallographic data for the structures determined in this study are listed in Tables −4.

This compound released part of its included water and ethanol at room temperature under vacuum. Anal. Calcd for [Zn(SO4)(BPU)(H2O)](EtOH)0.5: C, 34.59; H, 3.63; N, 13.44. Found: C, 34.62; H, 3.52; N, 13.68. Colorless crystals of 2 were obtained in a few days by layering a solution of BPU (0.21 g, 0.1 mmol) in 15 mL of acetone over a solution of ZnSO4⋅7H2O (0.029 g, 0.1 mmol) in 5 mL of water. 

 [Cu(NO  3  )(BPU)  2  ](NO  3  )(H  2  O)  2.5  (MeOH)  0.5   (3). A solution of Cu(NO3)2⋅2.5H2O (0.023 g, 0.1 mmol) in 2 mL of MeOH was layered  over a solution of BPU (0.043 g, 0.2 mmol) in 4 mL of CH2Cl2 and 1 mL of MeOH. Blue crystals of 3 were formed in one week and were filtered and washed with CH2Cl2. Yield: 0.054 g (80%). Anal. Calcd for [Cu(NO3)(BPU)2](NO3)(H2O)2.5(MeOH)0.5: C, 39.91; H, 4.02; N, 20.69. Found: C, 39.62; H, 3.68; N, 19.81. 

 [Cu(BPU)  2  (H  2  O)](SO  3  CF  3  )(H  2  O) (4). A solution of BPU (0.043 g, 0.2 mmol) in 3 mL of EtOH was layered over a solution of Cu(SO3CF3)2 (0.036 g, 0.1 mmol) in 2 mL of water. Blue crystals of 4 were collected after two weeks and washed with water and ethanol. Yield: 0.44 g (53%). Anal. Calcd for [Cu(BPU)2(H2O)](SO3CF3)(H2O): C, 34.89; H, 2.93; N, 13.56. Found: C, 35.09; H, 2.89; N, 13.34. 

 [Zn(BPU)  2  ](ClO  4  )  2   (5) and [Zn(BPU)  2  (H  2  O)  4  ](ClO  4  )  2  (BPU)  2   (6). A solution of Zn(ClO4)2⋅6H2O (0.037 g, 0.1 mmol) in 2 mL of EtOH was layered over a solution of BPU (0.043 g, 0.2 mmol) in 4 mL of chloroform and 1 mL of EtOH. Colorless crystals of 5 were collected after one week and washed with EtOH and chloroform. Yield: 0.064 g (92%). Anal. Calcd for [Zn(BPU)2](ClO4)2: C, 38.14; H, 2.91; N, 16.18. Found: C, 37.78; H, 3.05; N, 15.85. Colorless crystals of 6 were obtained by slow evaporation of a solution of Zn(ClO4)2⋅6H2O (0.037 g, 0.1 mmol) and BPU (0.043 g, 0.2 mmol) in EtOH (3 mL)/water (3 mL). 

 [Ag(NO  3  )(BCPU)] (7). A solution of AgNO3 (0.017 g, 0.1 mmol) in 2 mL of MeOH was layered over a solution of BCPU (0.052 g, 0.2 mmol) in 2 mL of acetone and 1 mL of chloroform. Colorless crystals of 7 were collected after one week and washed with MeOH and acetone. Yield: 0.040 g (93%). Anal. Calcd for [Ag(NO3)(BCPU)]: C, 41.69; H, 2.33; N, 16.21. Found: C, 41.45; H, 2.37; N, 15.90. 

 [Ag(SO  3  CH  3  )(BPU)  2  ] (8). A solution of AgSO3CH3 (0.020 g, 0.1 mmol) in 3 mL of MeOH was layered over a solution of BCPU (0.052 g, 0.2 mmol) in 2 mL of acetone and 1 mL of chloroform. Colorless crystals of 8 were collected after 3 days and washed with MeOH and acetone. Yield: 0.028 g (38%). Anal. Calcd for [Ag(SO3CH3)(BPU)2]:C, 51.18; H, 3.19; N, 15.40. Found: C, 50.88; H, 2.90; N, 15.48.
